review.title: Efficient Social Network Multilingual Classification using Character, POS n-grams and Dynamic Normalization
review.abstract: In this paper we describe a dynamic normalization process applied to social network multilingual documents (Facebook and Twitter) to improve the performance of the Author profiling task for short texts. After the normalization process, $n$-grams of characters and n-grams of POS tags are obtained to extract all the possible stylistic information encoded in the documents (emoticons, character flooding, capital letters, references to other users, hyperlinks, hashtags, etc.). Experiments with SVM showed up to 90% of performance.

sections.heading: 1 INTRODUCTION
sections.text: Social networks are a resource that millions of people use to support their relationships with friends and family (Chang et al., 2015). In June 2016, Facebook1 reported that they have about 1.13 billion active users per day; while in June Twitter2 averaged 313 million active users per month.Due to the large amount of information that is continuously produced on social networks to identify specific individual characteristics of users, the use of paper has been a problem of growing importance for different areas such as forensics, security and marketing (Rangel et al., 2015); problem that author profiling assumes an automatic classification approach based on the premise that depending on the individual characteristics of each person; such as age, gender or personality, the type of communication will be different. Author profiling is traditionally applied in texts such as literature, documentation or essays (Argamon et al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al, 2003; Argamon et al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al, 2009); this type of text has a relatively long duration (2011).

sections.heading: 2 AGE, GENDER AND PERSONALITY TRAITS PREDICTION
sections.text: (Koppel et al., 2002) conducted an investigation using a corpus of 566 documents from the British National Corpus (BNC) 3 in which they automatically identified the gender of the author using function words and POS n-grams, achieving an accuracy of 80% using a linear delimiter. (Doyle and Kes, 2005) constructed a simple classifier to predict the gender in a collection of 495 essays from the BAWE corpus. The classifier consisted in measuring the distance between the text to be classified and two different profiles (man and woman), being the smallest class assigned to the text. An accuracy of 81% was obtained using characters, words and POS n-grams as features.In (Peersman et al., 2011), the authors collected 1.5 million samples from the netlog social network to predict the age and gender of the authors. They used a 1998 model of two words (SVM), with the help of two words (SVM).

sections.heading: 3 CHARACTER AND POS
sections.text: N-GRAMSn-grams are sequences of elements of a selected text information unit (Manning und Schütze, 1999) that allow the extraction of content and stylistic features from the text; features that can be used in tasks such as automatic summary, automatic translation and text classification (e.g. in automatic translation and summary, word and phrasegrams are frequently used (Torres-Moreno, 2014; Giannakopoulos et al., 2008; Koehn, 2010); and within the text classification, plagiarism detection, author identification and author profiling; characters, word and POS n-grams are used (Doyle and Kes, 2005; Stamatos et al., 2015; Stamatos et al.; Oberreuter and Vela, quez, 2013).The information units selected in this study are characters and POS tags.

sections.heading: 4 DYNAMIC CONTEXT-DEPENDENT NORMALIZATION
sections.text: To minimize these variations, it is necessary to normalize those elements that are able to provide stylistic information independently of their lexical variability (references to other users, hyperlinks, hashtags, emoticons, etc.), which is what we call dynamic context-dependent normalization, which is divided into two phases: text normalization and POS relabeling. • Text normalization The goal of this phase is to avoid the lexical variability that exists when a user tends to perform certain actions in their texts; for example, marking another user or creating a link to a website. In the case of Twitter, references to other users as @ {username} are defined. The amount of values that can be assigned to the label are the elements that can be assigned to the username that are potentially infinite (depending on the number of users available to the social network).

sections.heading: 5 DATASETS
sections.text: To test different contexts, we used corpora from two social networks: Twitter and Facebook.The multilingual corpus PAN-CLEF2015 (Twitter) is labeled by gender, age and personality traits, while the multilingual corpus PAN-CLEF2016 (Twitter) is labeled by gender and age only. The Mexican Spanish corpus "Comments from Mexico City over time" (Facebook) is labeled by gender only.

sections.heading: 5.1 PAN-CLEF2015
sections.text: The PAN-CLEF2015 corpus7 (Rangel et al., 2005) consists of 324 samples distributed in four languages: Spanish, English, Italian and Dutch. A more complete description of the corpus can be found in Gonza ́ lezGallardo et al., 2016.

sections.heading: 5.2 PAN-CLEF2016 s
sections.text: The multilingual corpus of PAN-CLEF2016 is a set of training corpus for the author profiling task of PAN 2016.8 It consists of 935 samples marked by age and gender, distributed in three languages: Spanish, English and Dutch. In our experiments, only the gender label was taken into account. Table 2 shows the distribution of gender samples per language.

sections.heading: 5.3 Comments of Mexico City through time (CCDMX)
sections.text: The CCDMX corpus consists of 5,979 Mexican-Spanish comments from the Mexico City Facebook page to time9. This Facebook page posts images of Mexico City so people can share their memories and anecdotes, with an average length of 110 characters. The CCDMX corpus was manually commented on by undergraduate language students from UNAM's Group on Language Engineering (GIL) in 201410. It is marked by gender only, slightly higher than the number of comments in the "men" class (see Table 3).

sections.heading: 6 LEARNING MODEL
sections.text: For the experiments, we used support vector machines (SVM) (Vapnik, 1998), a classical model of supervised learning that has proven robust and efficient in various NLP tasks. In particular, we use the Python package Scikit-learn11 (Pedregosa et al., 2011) with a linear kernel (LinearSVC) that yielded empirically the best results.

sections.heading: 6.2 Experimental Protocol
sections.text: Four experiments were conducted with the PANCLEF2015 corpus; one for each language. 70% of the samples were used for training the learning model and the remaining 30% were used during the evaluation time.With regard to the PAN-CLEF2016 corpus, three experiments were performed; one for Dutch, one for English and one for Spanish. We used the training model created with the PAN-CLEF2015 corpus and applied it to this corpus. All samples available in the PAN-CLEF2016 corpus were used as gender classification tests.Three experiments were performed with the CCDMX corpus. • First, all comments were tested as test samples using the learning model created with the Spanish training samples of the PAN-CLEF2015 corpus. • For the second experiment, samples of 50 comments were created. Thus, 121 samples were tested with the same learning model of the first experiment. • Finally, the third experiment was the sum of different LECAN micro-samples of the 2015 corpus.

sections.heading: 7 RESULTS
sections.text: In order to evaluate the performance of the model in all datasets, a group of classical measures was implemented: Accuracy (A), Precision (P), Recall (R) and F-Score (F) (Manning and Guards, 1999) were used to evaluate gender and age predictions. In terms of predicting personality traits in the PANCLEF2015 corpus, the Root Mean Squared Error Measurement (RMSE) was used.

sections.heading: 7.1 PAN-CLEF2015 Corpus
sections.text: Tables 4 to 7 show the results of the PANCLEF2015 corpus for Spanish and English. Evaluation standards show practically 100% gender classification for Italian and Dutch (Gonza ́ lezGallardo et al., 2016), probably because the number of existing samples for both languages was very low. We think it would be worth trying to validate the results in these two languages with a larger amount of data. • Spanish.

sections.heading: 7.2 PAN-CLEF2016 s Corpus
sections.text: As can be seen in Tables 8 to 10, the performance of the experiments in all three languages is low. We believe that this is caused by the difference between the size of the samples used for the model (PAN-CLEF2015 corpus) and the size of the PAN-CLEF2016 corpus samples. Another possible reason is that the amount of noise in the PANCLEF2016 corpus was too large to be handled by the trained models, resulting in false predictions. • Spanish. • English.

sections.heading: 7.3 CCDMX Corpus
sections.text: The first experiment (E1), which was conducted with this corpus, aimed to find out how much influence the difference between the training and test samples had; the training phase was conducted with 70% of the samples from the PAN-CLEF2015 corpus (Spain); remember that one sample of this corpus represents a group of about 100 Tweets.Table 11 shows the results of the 5,979 samples tested; in the second experiment (E2) we decided to generate samples with 50 comments, the size of which represents a reasonable compromise between the number of samples and the characters per sample (about 5K characters).A total of 121 samples were tested with the learning model of E1; the results are slightly better than E1, but the domain difference seems to have a significant impact on system performance (Table 12).A third experiment (E3) was conducted with this corpus; eleven micro-experiments with different numbers of comments per sample were performed: 1, 4, 8, 4, 41, 57, 64, 57, 57, and 64.

sections.heading: 8 CONCLUSIONS AND FUTURE WORK
sections.text: Character and POS-n-grams have proved to be a useful resource for the extraction of stylistic features in short texts. Character-n-grams have been able to extract emoticons, punctuation exaggerations (flood of characters), the use of uppercase letters, and various types of emotional information in tweets and comments; interaction between the specific elements of social networks, such as references to users, hashtags, or links, and the rest of the POS tags have subsequently been captured with the POS-n-grams; it has also been possible for Spanish and English to capture the most representative set of two and three grammatical elements; for the Italian and Dutch, we have been able to capture the most common grammatical elements; the dynamic context-dependent normalization has been shown to be effective in the different domains (Facebook and Twitter), but also showed problems when cross-domain evaluation has been conducted; the poor results obtained in E1 reflect that it is important to maintain the trait-train-to-test ratio.
